text: Jacques Ellul (January 6, 1912 – May 19, 1994) was a French philosopher, sociologist, theologian, and Christian anarchist. He wrote several books about the "technological society", and about Christianity and politics, such as Anarchy and Christianity (1991) – anarchism and Christianity are socially following the same goal. A philosopher who approached technology from a deterministic viewpoint. Ellul was professor at the University of Bordeaux. He authored some 40 books and hundreds of articles over his lifetime, the dominant theme of which has been the threat to human freedom and Christian faith created by modern technology. Ellul spoke often about the emergence of a "technological tyranny" over humanity.Ellul, Jacques. The Technological Society, trans. John Wilkinson (New York: Random House, 1964), 79. Ellul has been credited with saying the phrase, "Think globally, act locally."Marlin, Randal. (2002) Propaganda and the Ethics of Persuasion.
